title: Why was blancmange considered to be the ideal dish for the sick in the Middle Ages? - Quora

response.answer_text: Possibly because it was tasty and easily digestible, although to be honest I suspect it was a rich person's dish in the Middle Ages, and acquired its place on the invalid diet sheet in Victorian times, when it was a sweetened, flavoured, milk pudding set with cornflour. The name means, literally, white (thing) to eat, from French blanc manger. Chaucer spelt it blankmanger. Medieval blancmange was more savoury: a typical recipe included almonds, milk or almond milk, and chicken mashed to a paste or in chunks, all thickened with rice flour and served with a sprinkling of sugar over it. Here's a typical recipe: Blankmanger.
